Back now with DAY TO DAY, and the big flurry of new movies this weekend.
Here is Mark Jordan Legan with our weekly look at what the critics think.
Slate's summary judgment.
Writer-director Noah Baumbach, who had the art house hit ""The Squid and the Whale,"" has cast his wife, Jennifer Jason Leigh, in his new film.
She and Nicole Kidman play battling sisters in the dark comedy ""Margot at the Wedding.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Margot at the Wedding"")
(As Pauline) I don't know where to begin, what can I tell you?
Seems I'm pregnant.
But it's really early, so I haven't told anyone.
I haven't told Malcolm or Ingrid.
What you say?
(As Margot) I said wow.
(As Pauline) Yeah, if it sticks.
We'll see.
Entertainment Weekly calls Kidman sensational, and the Hollywood Reporter raves: a wryly observed, bracingly original winner.
But many think Baumbach is an acquired taste.
New York magazine says: ""Margot at the Wedding"" doesn't develop, it just skips from one squirmy scene to the next.
And if you have small kids like I do, you'll have no choice but to check out Dustin Hoffman and Natalie Portman in ""Mr.
Magorium's Wonder Emporium,"" about a magical toy store.
Jason Bateman also stars.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Mr.
Magorium's Wonder Emporium"")
(As Edward Magorium) The hotdog to hotdog bun ratio.
Why, for the love of mustard, was there never enough buns?
(As Henry Weston) Extra hotdogs.
(As Edward Magorium) Yes.
But why?
(As Henry Weston) In case you drop a couple.
(As Edward Magorium) What kind of insufferable fool drops a hotdog?
Many critics complain of too much darn whimsy, but the Seattle Post- Intelligencer advises: it's well made and adults likely will find themselves yielding to its gentle, whimsical charm.
See, there's that whimsy you've all been warned about.
But hey, who needs whimsy when you have a motion-capture computer-generated version of the classic epic poem ""Beowulf""?

That's right, the old English chestnut that many of us were forced to read in high school has now been slicked up a la ""300,"" with buff warriors, battling monsters, and Angelina Jolie - not necessarily in that order.
Crispin Glover provides the voice of ""Grendel,"" and here is Ray Winstone as ""Beowulf.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Beowulf"")
Unidentified Man #1: (As character) Who are you?
(As Beowulf) I'm Beowulf, son of Ecgpeow.
They say you have a monster here?
They say your lands are cursed.
Unidentified Man #1: (As character) Is that what they say?
There's no shame to be accursed by demons.
I am Beowulf and I am here to kill your monster.
English Lit professors, hold on to your hats.
The critics like it.
Not for the adaptation but for the visuals.
Beowulf"" is also playing in a few IMAX theaters with 3D, so you can imagine what that's like.
What with a whole bunch of Jolie jumping out at you.
The BBC snarls: flat, sexy and absurd.
But the Arizona Republic cheers: exciting, fun and occasionally breathtaking.
And USA Today shouts: a sight to behold, exhilarating and kinetic.
Wow, if ""Beowulf"" rings up big box office, look for Hollywood to adapt other literary epic poems.

From hot new writer Jeffrey Chaucer comes the high-octane action thriller of the year, ""The Canterbury Tales."" Bruce Willis is the Knight and Tom Cruise is the Friar as they get ready to kick some 15th century (bleep).
Mark Jordan Legan is a Los Angeles writer and lover of Chaucer.
Let's turn now to Iraq.
The most widespread protests since 2003 are sweeping through the southern part of the country right now.
Demonstrators have been gathering for a week.
They are demanding jobs, also better services.
And in response to this, the Iraqi government has sent army and counterterrorism troops.
NPR's Jane Arraf has been monitoring these protests, and she joins us from Amman, Jordan.
Hi, Jane.
